author: chrissorem
content: This made me think of a production technique Ive stumbled on.  We all have our go to instincts that can lead to a similar feeling across a  record.  Generally there is a dominant instrument that the song was written on such as guitar or piano maybe a synth.  Take a filled out productions and mute all the main ingredients and leave the additive colors, only the sprinkles on top. And start rebuilding the production around that. It can take you to an entirely different  universe and provide contrast in the arch of the record

Oliver power tools and kshmr are the most useful and most modern packs. Not sure what kind of music you're making but for my workflow I like doing whatever I feel on a production and then having quick "modern" drum sounds I can reach for that immediately can put things into the present.

I'm doing a production right now for a UK artist where they gave me a throwback sounding demo, but I know the artist is a young 2023 female pop star. So I did a bunch of organic shit (acoustic through my 67, some live claps, shit like that), then I threw some kshmr and oliver loops in to just see what the hybrid of classic and modern sounds like. Production is basically done now

author: oaklandmatt
content:
There is a much longer answer, but essentially you learn that they are not opposites. You can overthink repeatedly on your way to finishing. 

It's not a straight line where you're productively working toward better. It's about always striving toward the absolute best you can get by exhausting your ideas and making the best decision you can in the moment. 

Art is subjective, so there's actually no "better." If you build up all these little skills (from keyboard shortcuts to emotional vulnerability in a writing session) and add that to repetitions, all you need is a relentless will to finish at the highest standard and you'll have a serious career.

Spoiler alert: the relentless will to finish is the hard part.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I couldn't speak to the current state of samplers, but I've always wished that someone would build a bold sampler that wasn't afraid to be really wacky and full of unique characteristics. For starters:

1. Include a radio tuner. 
2. Maybe some really nice - but heavily colored - preamps.
3. Include all kinds of weird peripheral sensors like devices that pick up EMF signals or a few contact mics. Include a suite of effect plugins that are specially geared towards these input methods.
4. Super-intuitive resampling, time-stretching, and pitch-shifting features.
5. An algorithm that analyzes the dominant pitch of a loop and auto-maps it to a keyboard. It should be capable of re-orienting itself as the dominant pitch of a loop is adjusted.
6. Tracker-style sequencing capabilities.
7. An OTT-style compressor. Maybe something really trashy and blown-out like Devil-Loc or Vulf Compressor. Something that really messes with the proportions of a sample.
8. Easy and flexible integration of feedback loops.
9. Intuitive integration of polyrhythmic looping or sequencing.
10. A feature for easy implementation of Steve Reich 'It's Gonna Rain' style tape loop phasing.
11. Auto-bpm detection keyed off of designated inputs (ala Ableton).
12. Automated master tempo effects.

I could go on.

author: popaganda.
content: I’ll add kind of a different angle to this convo….everything mentioned is crucial…play a lot, record, play with others, just reps….but if you want to see big gains TECHNICALLY on something like guitar or piano, you need to break movements down and very very slowly drill the transitions….one note to the next. One chord to the next…really building muscle memory. For a new chord shape…form it very slowly and then let go completely. Repeat many times. Same thing for chord transitions….super slowly between the two. It may seem like it would take too long to practice like that, but doing micro work like that will completely transform your ability on an instrument if you’re judicious and persistent.

author: Slow Hand
content:
At the risk of stating the obvious, transitions can also be telegraphed through the instrumental writing too. Whether it's a drum fill, or a chord voicing that walks up/down into the next section, or tension in the melodic voices, or shortening the notes lengths (staccato, staccatissimo).

There's also idiomatic noises from the instruments. Guitars have string scrapes, headstock rakes, that cool chattering thing from tapping near the bridge with the edge of your pick. Pianos have big glisses, horns can squeal, bowed strings can sweep a fast legato scale up into the downbeat or do a large gliss.

Then there's foley. I get a *lot* of mileage from sound libraries made for film audio. Foley artists are some creative people and you can go far layering their sounds into instruments at the transitions.

author: bobby k
content: I will say this, on the topic of standing up for yourself -- I've seen a couple times in these threads now a general sentiment of accepting that people are gonna kick you around. It felt evident when we were riffing on sliding scale mixing rates last month and it felt evident this morning/last night in here. I'm all in on the greyhound sentiment, I've been a grafter through and through since I was in elementary school skipping homework to double up on piano practice. I once drove 7 hours to buy a Juno-60 on Craigslist and the guy didn't answer the door; I make DUMB life decisions all centered around this non-negotiable gravity towards the art. I can promise I have whatever that obsessive brain disorder thing is that we all keep riffing about (and believe the same for the grand majority here). But can we not practice a little self preservation along the way? Nobody besides your team is really gonna stick up for you; I believe that in line with the all the professional metrics there exists the opportunity/need to set  precedents on how you want to be treated. I don't think this is something that *comes* with being a great producer, I think it's something that *contributes* to someone becoming a great producer. And of course, knowing how to ask for that fairness with a kind/patient/assertive/flexible tone is critical. But if I believe something is a little crooked in the system, I'd rather not wait till I hopefully arrive a decade later on the other side of the fence to be able to do something about it. I would rather make an attempt at being heard now and see whether it makes any progress, even if it just gives some suit on an email thread something to think about. It's not for the sake of my own ego, it's for the sake of our entire breed.

author: Zach Hughes
content:
Wanted to share some thoughts spurred on by a recent experience on here. So a local artist has hired me to produce two of her songs. Vibe is singer-songwriter, soul, RnB.

We tracked drums, bass, and keys live in the studio OD'd to scratch tracks we cooked up together. The scratch tracks / demos were just guitar vocal and we were really relying on the players to fill out the arrangements, but we knew more would be added down the line.

All the players were incredible. Could singe your eyebrows off with technical prowess and shredtastic chops. Tracks turned out great, still working on the arrangement, but..

This project has got me thinking more about the importance of how you present a song to session musicians and the 'space' you ask them to fill in a production. As well as the changing dynamics project to project affected by a revolving cast of participants, more fleshed out demos, etc... I find this a really interesting topic. Curious if anyone in the group has any unique experiences or insights whether as a producer or a musician.

I've found that the more I flesh out demos with the artist beforehand the more bound and limited the session players we bring in are based off our decisions. This can make ODs more efficient, add a clearer direction, but can also remove the opportunity for the player to really add something special. Sometimes I don't want to be too suggestive b/c I want the players to have more of a blank canvas to work with.

author: wilhelmjosephk
content: One thing I love to do to help me wrap my head around sounds and tools is basically “transcribing” a preset to a new initialized patch on the same synth. Keep hitting the keys as you go to see how copying each setting changes the sound, and see if the end result is the same when you think you’re done. Often you’ll be completely missing some modulator somewhere and you’ll really need to dig through the synth’s features to find something you didn’t know before. As a bonus, you can try the same thing but have the synth that the preset comes from and the synth you’re recreating it in be two different tools, like trying to remake you’re favorite serum patch in Pigments. Sometimes certain features will be missing outright and you’ll just have to use your ears to get close, but I find this really useful for figuring the inherent differences in the tools at my disposal. Best thing about both of these exercises is they only take about 10-15 minutes a patch, then you’re on to something new

author: peterlabberton
content:
I’m a drummer first, but now play bass/guitar/some minimal keys on a good amount of stuff I produce. Taking drums out of the equation (that was years and years of many many hours every day), I’ve just gradually improved on the other instruments to a point where I now feel comfortable playing on a record. There have been moments of sustained growth in a given instrument, but really it’s just been time and growing as a *musician*—almost more a mindset of confidence. A baseline level of theory helps, then just a) learning songs, and b) learning how to play what you want to hear.

Also editing. Not gonna throw this person under the bus, but I got to work with a very A-list producer a couple years ago and recorded him playing drums (not his main instrument). Let’s just say it wasn’t great. But it got the idea down, and then edit edit edit. No shame, just make it great in the end!

author: oaklandmatt
content:
I will say I don't think it's all about their vision or when they want to pivot. It's a bit more nuanced. 

If you are truly a producer collaborator (as opposed to a hired gun engineer or musician), it's about trying all the ideas and collectively deciding what's best. But remember YOU are the one who holds the keys to the execution of the artist's ideas. You can have ideas and try them yourself, but if the artist has ideas, it's still YOU that has to execute them (because presumably they're not a producer like you). 

So you're actually building a big creative trust by helping the artist try stuff. If you can execute ideas that the artist can't quite articulate or do themselves, you gain a credibility where you can both listen and then say "Ah, I see what you mean. I think this other version is best."

author: Slow Hand
content:
Yup! Massive was my go-to for years prior to Massive X.

The biggest change for me is that the raw oscillators sound far better. The original Massive had a lot of aliasing that could make it sound hazy and flat. Switching over to Massive X it is crystal clear and even buzzy saw waves feel warm, pure, and tactile.

It has extremely flexible modulation capabilities that I find to be very musical as well as some very comprehensive ADSHR envelopes. It also has four different keyboard tracking curves that you can assign and tweak, which is very important when fine-tuning your patch to make sure that it sounds even across the entire range of keys.

It has a lot of musical sounding filters that can inject a ton of vibe, or be completely neutral. The *noise* section is robust and very flexible. I use it a lot.

Finally, it has a great-sounding set of internal effects (delay, chorus, saturation, verb, etc) that can be placed anywhere inside of the routing diagram. It's always a bummer when the on-board effects aren't very inspiring. But NI has a strong catalog of well-designed dsp to draw on and integrate into their products, so it's turned out great.

Overall, it's a very robust and well-rounded synthesizer that also does a lot of things extremely well. It can be super clean (like Serum) but also get very dirty, which I appreciate in a synth.

The only thing I don't like is that the preset browser kind of sucks. I prefer the original Massive's browser. NI is well aware and they have been overhauling it and slowly adding new features, so I trust in time this will be made better.

author: spectrummasters
content: Logic Gang: quick share, Im finding the sample delay tool v useful in a few ways and reccommend for a few reasons. Picking up on the midi ticks convo last week, if youre programming in Logic , instead of dragging (and losing track of your moves) in the timeline/piano roll....throw one of these on an insert and increase the delay in tiny increments as you run down the track (typically hats and offbeat/ghost snares first) . You can quickly create the pocket youre looking for . Also added bonus...I believe under c. 12ms most people arent hearing a glaring time shift , (i dont go above 2ms ) so the delay is handy again just putting your hats , snares, percussive elements....just a millisecond or two behind/in front of each other so all your transient sounds are not hitting the 1/4,1/8, 16th counts at precisely the same instant. I find this helps with transients. Lastly, unlink the left and right on a stereo channel and youve got an instant width tool. Best for the transient and groove use tho imo.

author: NoahNeedleman
Slow Hand
content:
I don't know that music being hard is necessarily a good thing for it's own sake. I'd rather have it be easy and lower the friction between conception and realization. A lot of tech these days enables that ease and has opened the door to more people writing and producing their records.

But a secondary side-effect that I think we can all observe - and I think this is more to your point - is that musicians are leaning into those methods and not pursuing the hard work and practice that is necessary to do things like singing well, or playing piano with more than a base level of proficiency, or orchestrating an ensemble well. The expressive unlock of being highly proficient isn't being pursued like it was in the past decades (before we had so may technological means). People are - broadly speaking - more satisfied these days to settle for records that don't push into that potential.

What we lose are the heights of expression that virtuosity unlocks. Whether that's singing like Aretha Franklin, or playing a simple ballad like Bill Evans, or writing a song with as much sophistication and lyrical wit as Joni Mitchell.

author: Slow Hand
content:
*Keyscape* has some fantastic sounding (and unorthodox) sampled keyboard instruments. That said I'm not particularly fond of the sound of it's LA Custom C7 grand piano. Which is a little too hi-fi for my taste.

Lately I've been very impressed by NI's/Kontakt's *The Maverick* grand piano. I believe it's a vintage Bechstein grand. The sound is robust and rich without all of the "zing" that I see in a lot of full-scale sampled grand pianos. It sounds "woody" to me. I think it would make for a very nice jazz piano.

They did a really good job of sampling every facet it and it has enough flexibility that you can dial in the really intimate Nils Frahm-style damper/pedal/mechanical noises, which I like.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Oh, just one more thing. I find it very helpful to practice making patches by trying to emulate a given instrument's expression. I'm primarily thinking about note articulation, here. Modeling these behaviors is a good way to start thinking musically with a synthesizer.

So if I'm going for a "horn" instrument I want a patch that can do attack-y stabs, but also fade into notes and have complete dynamic control. It should also have some sort of brightness feature that I can open up at will, like blowing harder into some brass.

If I'm emulating a voice there's going to be a big emphasis on legato playing and fluidity, with some very expressive pitch control for bends and vibrato. Maybe some form of subtle formant control to shade the notes like a singer would with different vowel sounds.

An organ patch is going to be a dead simple note-on/note-off volume envelope with the expression coming from the addition or subtraction of different oscillators.

And some patches are just going to be gangly chaotic messes that you do your best to wrangle. Something with a lot of chaos and feedback and squealing. You can't control it, but you just strap in.

author: gatewoodsensei
content:
I’m not sure if this’ll help, but I tend to go with whatever hits me at the time. If it’s a melody, I’ll sing it, mumble words, and allow the music to form around that idea. If it’s lyrics, then i grab a guitar or sit in front of the keyboard and play the accompaniment. Or if I’m in front of my computer, and melody line hits, I’ll play the melody, or chords and allow it to loop while I write. So I don’t necessarily balance, because to me that means I’m shutting part of my creativity off i order to allow the other part to flow, and more often than not, that kills the creative flow. 

So don’t try to balance anything. Whatever you feel, go with that and allow your creativity to flow.

author: Slow Hand
content:
A few things:

1. What kind of samples are we talking about syncing here? Short samples like drums and loops? Or heavy sampled instruments like a piano/string library? Or both? 

2. I think the equivalent syncing feature in Dropbox would be "make available offline". If you right click a folder and "make available offline" it will continually update when it receives uploads from the other computer. Have you used that before? It doesn't have the lightning speed of a local network/ethernet connection, but if you can wait a few minutes it's good.

3. I assume these are Ableton sessions. Do you ever use the 'collect all and save' feature when saving sessions? It will gather every external sample (but not sampled instrument libraries) and save them to the project folder, which will save you the trouble of having to point your Ableton session to any external directory, because it will all be in the project folder. Very good when it comes to archiving sessions and opening them up years later.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
On the 3-4 patches: what are they? I’m imagining one attacky bass, a pad that works in lower/mid/upper registers, a good playable poly keys patch with enough editable character to slot into different tracks… 

Presumably you find they cover enough bases, but I’d be wondering if having such a limited palette would narrow the variety of what I’m going to come out with. Often times it’s flipping through presets and finding something very unique sounding that will inspire a part that inspires a track for me.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Totally. 

So I should clarify a little bit. These 3-4 patches aren't static sounds that I never change. Think of them more like initialized synth templates with pre-determined routings and modulation that I can start with and then diverge from. I still use other people's presets, but using these templates can save me a good 15 minutes every time that I want to build a new patch and don't want to start all the way from scratch. They come with a lot of built-in expression.

On most of these I've got a lot of the keyboard tracking already tuned so that a bright patch doesn't get too harsh as I go up in register or it doesn't get too flabby and lose definition in the low-end.

I've got one patch set up for very expressive pitch modulation. Lots of big sweeps and bends in the attack/release envelope phases. Think wonky Neptunes-type sounds or two-octave dive bombs. Stuff like that.

One patch is set for expressive filter and amplitude modulation. Wobbles, envelope modulations, and such. It's my go-to if I'm trying to play with some "brassy" dynamics.

One is a legato mono patch for very fluid vocal-like playing. A big emphasis on note articulation and variation. I think of it as a solo instrument.

The final one is (you called it) A nice poly synth. Think James Blake on a Prophet. Pretty standard stuff, but once again it's got keyboard tracking that's tuned up so that the patch feels rich across the entire range.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
From a cursory Synthtopia scan:

"So it seems that Luis Fernando Zepeda is part of the Organist generation of 60s-70s Mexico City with others like Evaristo Enriquez or Juan Torres.
This technique was “invented” by Tito Enriquez but perfected by Ernesto “Hill” Gil Olvera, whom was blind, and recorded LPs under the advertising that he played “the Organ that Talks!”

I found on a random blog that the drawbar configuration was something like this, you started with:
A = 88 8000 000 00
E = 80 8080 000 00
I = 80 0080 000 00
O = 80 8000 000 00
U = 80 0000 000 00

And you worked them with your left hand as you played with your right hand and play bass with with left foot and expression with right foot. It is a Hammond X66"


There's lots of Ernesto Gil Olvera stuff on YT, but I (and my nephew) don't like it is as much as this Luis Fernando Zepeda track. Can't find anything else by him unfortunately.

author: spectrummasters
content: With regards to making a call , I’d be interested in peoples perspectives . How do you make the call between following an artists ideas and helping them to articulate those ideas vs following your own instincts  that it’s time to move the process on and finish adding ideas in order to resolve and complete ? Ie . Recently I completed a project to master with an artist who was over the moon , planning the video ….no complaints , pure buzz , a few weeks later . I get the message “hey man I was just thinking what if we try and add a piano part “ . Imo the song doesn’t demand it , I suspect friends and armchair mozarts have thrown in their own 2 pence in the last few weeks and now what was in all our opinions 🔥, has to face tinkering . I don’t like telling people what to think , ie . I think you’re making a mistake …..but I don’t like overwriting songs , so for me it’s a obvious f that idea let’s just write another one  . I’d be interested in others internal dialogue with regards to when / if/ how you say no ….and if it sits with you alright personally or you find it problematic (and I ask this in order to find charming but assertive ways to keep the door closed on a project when it truly felt  finished to all involved  and went to full completion / master and release strategy and now as the producer you truly believe it can only be damaged by changes )

author: Slow Hand
content:
@Skyler Young This looks cool. A neat feature I'd love to see someday would be to add a simple EQ device and allow internal resampling of one-shot samples. The idea is that samples often have some boxiness or ringing that needs to be EQ'd out, but those problem-zones shift when the sample is transposed up and down, making any post-sampler EQ moves ineffectual.

If you could streamline the process of re-recording a static sample with the necessary EQ cuts committed into the one-shot then those cuts would be transposed along with the sample when you play it up and down the keyboard.

author: Zack Hames
content:
My MPC Live is my right hand man in the studio as a writing tool. But when im NOT making records and mixing and recording, I make industrial music entirely on hardware. So the MPC is the daw in this case. No computer. 

If I’m using the MPC on a production where it isn’t the brain, it gets a little cumbersome, sometimes I make stuff on it and simply record it analog into pro tools. Other times I actually export the “stems” on the MPC as it’s very easy then take the sd card and drop the files into the session. This is a little time consuming but works and sounds great. 

There is MPC software/plugin that works with it! I just haven’t integrated it with my daw yet, but it seems legit. 

I don’t program drums on a piano roll ever, I always hit the pads.

author: Deleted User
content:
it’s generally the orange if it’s something like palm muted guitars. But always listen and feel it. It can feel better to be early in certain styles but it can feel better to be late on other styles. it also depends on who else is doing what

But groove template is always there if you wanna line it up with other instruments. bounce and make the source and destination audio files the same length, make sure the markers are in the correct place then sync them up. 

I’m 90% manual editing though. Because aligning automatically can fix notes I didn’t want to fix. you can also go measure by measure to be more careful if you want to auto align with groove templates 

you want to ask yourself “is this note late or early?” before making any moves. I like nudging with keyboard so I can fine tune how far it goes. 

Nowadays I’m more committed to “the only way to make the groove feel good is to play it that way”. I hate having to edit and to be honest, nothing beats well played rhythm section… Especially because I do a lot of in between the groove stuff, 30% quantization can mess with the feel of well landed notes. So I’m doing a lot of metronome practice these days

author: cy (sigh)
content:
I produce /write  and mix. 
I'd say about 60% mix work but mostly cause the production stuff tends to make longer w my clients. 

I have no issues jumping from project to project but I personally HAVE TO have all ny task organized and planned in my head.  so either the night before or when I wake up (at 3am usually) I'll organize my tasks on Notion based on project urgency etc and pick 3 things I have to do and 3 things I'd like to do 

from then I just make sure to jump between what I have to do whenever I feel like there's no forward movement on something. the 3 extra things are backups that I jump to in case I'm really uninspired w the others for some reason.

I will say I use a timer to take 5-15mns breaks regularly and will often do short workouts to get the blood flowing which I find helps me maintain more consistent energy on long hauls 

if it's production work specifically I'll write down the tasks as specifically as possible and try to hits check point whiting 20-30mns if the goal is spcific enough,

author: Slow Hand
content:
Does anyone know if there's a program, synth, or protocol that allows you to modulate synthesizer envelope times based on the duration of the MIDI note?

For example, if I draw a quarter note (on the piano roll) and my synth plays a one octave downward sweep it would take a quarter note's worth of time to execute that sweep. But if I draw a MIDI note with a whole-note duration the synthesizer would modulate it's envelope time and that same sweep would descend over the course of a whole-note.

The synth would have to read upcoming MIDI note lengths from the the piano roll and modulate it's parameters on a note by note basis by reading the note duration before the note-on message. There would have to be some sort of communication between the synth and the DAW, and of course it would not work in real time.

author: Slow Hand
content: It would be cool if there was an ARA-like integration where the synthesizer's sequencer could exist in place of the piano roll.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Yeah. I'm excited to see what MIDI 2.0 can do, but I don't see many developers implementing it. Roland has released MIDI 2.0 keyboards, and the new line of NI keyboards seems to have it (though it may not be fully implemented).

I wonder when DAWs will start implementing it. I'm curious to know if having more CC resolution is going to make an appreciable difference in performance.

content: True....   for film score jobs,  I've stolen tips from Randy Newman....  I'll sit at the piano and just watch the scene and "church underscore" it by playing free time around the dialog.  Then come back and tempo map the click to what I had played.  Write the parts to that. Print the charts, and send the click map to the players.  In that case, it's both without and WITH a click.   It's not YES or NO.  It's both.

I did a thing for a new Duracell battery announcement video a few years ago, not as epic as the UN and world peace but it sounds like a similar vibe (two people in a clean corporate setting talking about their vision for the future, clean tech, innovation and legacy, nice B-roll etc). 

For this I did a simple high-shelved felt piano piece where it glided up and down, sometimes layered to give body and tension, and used soft white noise and other relatively muted tones to create movement and moments in the form of risers and sweeps etc. It was relatively unobtrusive and tonally appropriate for the subject matter, whilst being a little bit uplifting too.

author: Zack Hames
content:
So, I think it’s superbly underrated. Especially the new Akai MPC lives, one, etc series.

I use it as a drum machine/sampler/sequencer for all of my hardware synths. It’s the brain and controller for everything.

But you can also use it completely on its own, you can put any sample all the way across a keyboard/pads to the correct pitch automatically. 

There are built in AIR effects. You can time stretch, etc do whatever with samples. 

Load up any drum samples and go to town. 

It also has some built in instruments / synths, but I rarely use those. 

It’s essentially a portable DAW as far as music production. I prefer it to computer by far for producing / writing with samples and synths

author: Slow Hand
content:
Other strategies for re-vamping the feel and arrangement:
1. Trying putting instruments in different registers (move the bass up/down an octave).
2. Play the song in a neutral form like only piano and vocals and listen for what it might suggest.
3. Substitute instruments (Ex: bowed bass instead of electric bass).
4. Try a different key.
5. Try half-time. Try double-time.

author: chris_donlin
content: Love this question, I’ve been on a big panning journey the last two months because I’ve always just doubled things and panned everything evenly. I was listening to an episode on Sonic Scoop about Nigel Godrich’s approach to mixing and it was really eye opening to hear how bold his mixes are. I used to get distracted when something was panned but not balanced but after just forcing myself to do it I’ve gotten more comfortable, and even fallen a bit in love with what panning can do. I’ve noticed I have a tendency to pan instruments a certain way, pianos sound better panned, electric guitars always feel better panned right, no reason why it just does. Find what feels good to you! I haven’t gotten bold enough to pan bass and drums to a side. One day

author: Brian Reynolds
content: I'm always layering my melodic instruments in the stereo field. I imagine it like making a cold cut sandwich. Noah's comment unlocked something, I hadn't done before, moving the melody thru different layers. The main melodic guitar. I had it at like 60% where I normally leave it. But had it widen to over 80% in chorus. Then more narrow than I would normally have a doubled melodic at like 35%. Usually id just do one guitar, mono to scratch the scene change itch. I save hard panned left right area for chorus guitars or stereo stereo synths to swim in. That with dropping the piano for first half of verse 2 did the trick! Still hoping this is a catalyst for more sharing of ideas
